posts.cooked:
Hey! I have set up the swerve drive post estimator and I have set up path planning on the fly with path planner lib.

The way I have to set up is the first waypoint is the swerve pose estimators current position and then the second is the point I want to go to. However it first goes to the “initial position” (the parameter in the constructor) of the swerve drive pose estimator instead of just staying at its current position and then going to the final waypoint.

Any help would be super appreciated! 17407824154294475558566075473934 1920×1080 106 KB

17407824154294475558566075473934 1920×1080 106 KB

17407824154294475558566075473934 1920×1080 106 KB

posts.name: Val
posts.cooked: I think the issue is that the command is “generated” when the robot starts up! this means that the “waypointFromPoses” is called when the robot starts up and gets stored. Then when you press the button pathplanner tries to go to the start of the path which is the initial position that is passed in to the pose Estimator. This might not be the most effective solution but you could wrap the command in a Commands.defer(() → …, Set.of()) that way the command is generated when the button is pressed! Also be careful with using the swerve drive’s pose as a waypoint since the rotation of the pose isn’t the starting rotation, instead it’s the direction of travel!
Thanks for the response! I’ll try this now. Do you have any examples of the defer?

posts.name: Vihaan C
posts.cooked:
Here are the docs for it:

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command, class: DeferredCommand

So it would look something like this:
Yeah, I feel like I’m so close but I’m not sure what a  Set is
I figured it out!! Although, any tips on the heading issue of it being relative to the direction of travel and not the field? Is there a better way to do this whole setup?

posts.name: Val
posts.cooked: Yes! This is my favorite topic! So to create the path i recommend having your initial direction of travel be the direction of motion of the server drive. This has the benefit of being incredibly smooth when the driving is in motion. It runs into issues if the target and initial are right on top of each other or if the drive is standing still (in which case you’ll have to use IF statements for exceptions) We have some very messy code (and some cleaner untested code) that I can direct you towards if you want more clarification!

Yes that would be great,I would love to see both! I was planning on getting the April tags heading relative to the field and inputting that into the final way points heading but I am super curious to see what other teams do and how to make it more effective

posts.name: Val
posts.cooked:
